Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I glanced at my phone, reading her message again: “Can’t believe it’s our last weekend together before I leave. Let’s make it special.” My heart ached. I wanted nothing more than to hold her hand, walk by the river, and savor every moment before she flew across the world. But as I was locking up the mosque after Friday prayers, Brother Ahmed approached me, his voice low. “Imam, I could really use your advice. Whenever you have a moment this weekend?” His eyes were tired, hopeful. I knew he’d been struggling lately, and as imam, I was expected to be there—always ready to listen, to guide, to help. My mind spun with guilt and anxiety. My girlfriend needed me, craved my presence before her long absence. My community needed me, too, and I’d promised to serve them selflessly. I felt torn, the weight of both worlds pressing on my chest, unsure how to honor both without letting someone down.
